author: Robert Gibson
title: Egger directors highlight Brexit risks in letter to 500 employees
text:
Egger directors highlight Brexit risks in letter to 500 employees 16:38, 20 Jun 2016 16:39, 20 Jun 2016 By Robert Gibson Hexham business says leaving the EU would weaken sterling and negatively impact on its key sectors Shares Get business news by email An aerial view of the Egger facility at Hexham, Northumberland 
Directors at the Hexham-based forestry firm Egger have written to the company’s 500 employees, highlighting risks to the business in the event of Britain leaving the EU . 
The international company - which supplies wood for furniture, worktops and flooring across Europe – has told staff a weakened pound would damage its position in the UK and at its bases on the continent. 
It would also make securing supply materials more difficult. 
The letter to workers says: “Our merchandise sales deliver significant profit margins to the business, which would be undermined if sterling weakened on the back of a Leave outcome. “A weakened sterling would also have a similar, negative impact on essential raw material supplies (eg raw paper and chemicals).” 
The warning, signed by four company directors, adds that the firm’s medium-term growth is “based on economic stability”. 
“If the UK votes to leave the EU, consumer and market confidence would impact on our key sectors – furniture industry, interior design, wood construction and wood-based flooring,” it says. 
“We also believe that the EU without the UK would be economically weaker. 
“This could impact on the economic position of the remaining countries and therefore Egger’s own performance within these major European markets.” 
Guy Opperman, MP for Hexham , said: “I welcome Egger, like many other employers, setting out the risks to jobs we face from leaving the EU. 
“Almost all the experts agree our economy would suffer some like kind of economic shock if we were to Leave the EU. 
“That would hurt jobs and growth and it not a risk I am prepared to take with Tynedale’s future. 
“That is why I am voting Remain.”
